content.body: Dominic Farolino: no, a preflight only validates if the server is capable of handling the request, it doesn't validate if a specific resource wants to hand over data; you can kinda think of it as request vs response authorization
content.formatted_body: Dominic Farolino: no, a preflight only validates if the server is capable of handling the request, it doesn't validate if a specific resource wants to hand over data; you can kinda think of it as request vs response authorization

content.body: smaug: perhaps we could require element(s)-reflecting attributes to be connected and create more GC opportunities when they are not? Though I think this would require an element was disconnected listener to clear any cached object.
content.formatted_body: smaug: perhaps we could require element(s)-reflecting attributes to be connected and create more GC opportunities when they are not? Though I think this would require an element was disconnected listener to clear any cached object.

content.body: requiring some manual clearing is a problem. Easy to forget. (just this week analyzed a semi-large website which was leaking like crazy because they were not clearing something - this time it was JS objects though, not DOM nodes)
smaug: the disconnected listener would be part of the browser, to be clear
content.formatted_body: smaug: the disconnected listener would be part of the browser, to be clear

content.body: ah
connected elements are kept alive anyhow, so the reference could be then just weak, no? But do we expose GC behavior if one uses expando properties on disconnected nodes?
Hmm, and connected... what if the other node is moved to another Document, and that document itself would be GCed if there weren't these references? Or do we handle not-the-same-document somehow?
smaug: to handle that we'd need more listeners, which doesn't seem ideal
content.formatted_body: smaug: to handle that we'd need more listeners, which doesn't seem ideal

content.body: smaug: the reason the reference is strong is because it's a JS object
content.formatted_body: smaug: the reason the reference is strong is because it's a JS object

content.body: UI Events, sigh
Also wrote up the throw-or-not case, which was a fun bit of research https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/9045
`<dialog>` seems pretty inconsistent with itself

content.body: Jake Archibald: the concern with 4 does not apply to 3? Does each step on "update the rendering" end up running microtasks?
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: the concern with 4 does not apply to 3? Does each step on "update the rendering" end up running microtasks?

content.body: annevk: hmm, I guess it could be a problem if the change isn't triggered by script. There are microtask checkpoints within the render steps, but those are weird.
content.formatted_body: annevk: hmm, I guess it could be a problem if the change isn't triggered by script. There are microtask checkpoints within the render steps, but those are weird.

content.body: Good catch.
Actually, the changes would happen in a task, and there's always a microtask checkout afterwards
* Actually, the changes would happen in a task, and there's always a microtask checkpoint afterwards

m.new_content.body: Actually, the changes would happen in a task, and there's always a microtask checkpoint afterwards

content.body: I'm not concerned about running script with attribute changes, but `input` listeners running when the tree changes seems more concerning.
content.formatted_body: I'm not concerned about running script with attribute changes, but input listeners running when the tree changes seems more concerning.

content.body: annevk: the use-case would be, eg, transforming the input, like making it all uppercase, or auto inserting `-` in US phone numbers
content.formatted_body: annevk: the use-case would be, eg, transforming the input, like making it all uppercase, or auto inserting - in US phone numbers

content.body: By queuing a task, you risk a flash of content. Maybe `beforeinput` is better for this
content.formatted_body: By queuing a task, you risk a flash of content. Maybe beforeinput is better for this

content.body: * By queuing a task, you risk a flash of untransformed content. Maybe `beforeinput` is better for this
content.formatted_body: * By queuing a task, you risk a flash of untransformed content. Maybe beforeinput is better for this

m.new_content.body: By queuing a task, you risk a flash of untransformed content. Maybe `beforeinput` is better for this
m.new_content.formatted_body: By queuing a task, you risk a flash of untransformed content. Maybe beforeinput is better for this

content.body: Jake Archibald: surely each step in "update the rendering" doesn't equal a task?
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: surely each step in "update the rendering" doesn't equal a task?

content.body: I guess I don't actually really know how that works
annevk: there's a microtask checkpoint after running script, no matter where in the loop it happens
content.formatted_body: annevk: there's a microtask checkpoint after running script, no matter where in the loop it happens

content.body: Right, because there's not going to be script on the stack at that point.
Okay, I guess 3 could work. (Or generalize CEReaction.)
Hopefully it's not a breaking change ðŸ˜¬
Keeping it async reduces the risk I guess

Hi, I'm a DOM noob. Imagine you have a site e.g. "

Hello I am

very
funny.

Truly!". You get all the text: "Hello I am very funny. Truly". Now assume we put that text into some fancy algorithm and it gives us back "I am very" and you now wanna wrap that in a tag to highlight it. How would you do that? E.g. how would I get all the nodes corresponding to "I am very" s.t. I could get the "first" and "last" and add a resp. to it? Could I e.g. do something like number all the nodes and set up some mapping? Any input is welcome. :)
content.formatted_body: Hi, I'm a DOM noob. Imagine you have a site e.g. "<p>Hello <span>I <a href="#">am</a><div> very funny.</p><bold>Truly!</bold>". You get all the text: "Hello I am very funny. Truly". Now assume we put that text into some fancy algorithm and it gives us back "I am very" and you now wanna wrap that in a <mark></mark> tag to highlight it. How would you do that? E.g. how would I get all the nodes corresponding to "I am very" s.t. I could get the "first" and "last" and add a <mark> resp. </mark> to it? Could I e.g. do something like number all the nodes and set up some mapping? Any input is welcome. :)
